msgSnippet: I find it easier simply to import the source into VAJ and run the appropriate TestRunner directly. Is there such an advantage to configuring a tool for this

I find it easier simply to import the source into VAJ and run the
appropriate TestRunner directly. Is there such an advantage to configuring
a tool for this purpose? Anyone?

J. B. Rainsberger  <rainsber@...>
Commerce Suite Accelerator: Rule Services, IBM Toronto Lab
8200 Warden Av, Office A3-735 [A3/FNB/8200/MKM]
Markham ON   L6G 1C7
905 413-2501 (969-2501)


"Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...> on 06/20/2001 08:06:53

Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com

To:   "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
cc:
Subject:  RE: [junit] VisualAge JUnit



The tools in VAJ can be somewhat tricky.  Basically, there are two ways to
accomplish running anything from tools.

1. export .class files out to directory where the default.ini is, have the
default.ini refer to them as normal
2. don't export .class files out to directory where the default.ini is,
have
the default.ini refer to them as normal

Simple?  If you do #2, which I recommend, the added step is to put any
project you need in the workspace classpath (by default, we put every
project in there - but that's overkill).  You also need to make sure that
you have the referenced project that you want to access in your workspace
(I
know that sounds obvious, but just in case...).  In addition it is good to
have the VAJ Tools API projects in your workspace (and include them in the
workspace classpath).

How is your default.ini file constructed?

-Jason

subject: RE: [junit] VisualAge JUnit
